body:
You have to use req.files.avatar.path instead of req.files.avatar.data or req.files.avatar.data.toString('utf8'). I think, it should work. 
You can see "image uplod" example in the following link . 

https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/tree/master/samples/photo_album
dude, can you even read? I'm telling you, there is no such property as `req.files.avatar.path`. because it doesn't store anything to the disk.
Dude, I am reading but I think, this is the only way to upload photo. I didn't read any document about your case.
@roeeba didn't work. still tries to interpret it as a path and throws "ENAMETOOLONG"
I am working around for now by storing to a temp file and then cleaning it up after the upload to cloudinary succeeds.
Hi @r3wt , can you please share the full error message you've got (ENAMETOOLONG)?

It's annoying to have to convert buffers to DataURIs or write them to disk before uploading them. This is an unnecessary perf slowdown and it would make sense for the upload method to support the direct use of Buffers.
@roeeba no, i just decided to stop using cloudinary.

@r3wt I'm sorry to hear that, we're always here for any further assistance if you'd reconsider. If you'd still want to resolve this, and if you could please share some more context, e.g., a sample Data URI, we'll be happy to do our best to reproduce the issue on our end.

@karthikiyengar Thank you very much for this feedback. I've forwarded your feedback to our engineers to review.

upload_stream is better suited to buffers

```
cloudinary.uploader.upload_stream((result) => console.log(result))
.end(req.files.avatar.data)
```

`end` in this case is just passing in your buffer and indicating there won't be any further writes to the stream.

`upload_stream` is just a [thin wrapper](https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/master/src/uploader.coffee#L25) around `upload`, but it sets a `stream` flag. If you pass in a string `upload` is just going to treat it as a string and create a readStream from it.

just adding that if you only have one file using

`cloudinary.uploader.upload_stream( (result) => console.log(result) ).end( req.file.buffer )` will also work.

Notice the change fron **data** to **buffer**

Still the same issue
The JS docs are not helpful at all

from the docs

File:
```
the actual data (byte array buffer). 
For example, in some SDKs, this could be an IO input stream of the data (e.g., File.open(file, "rb")).
```

The Node.js documentation is very not documented. I had to guess many stuff my self and just started with debugging the Cloudinary object to find how to make it work
Hi, @KromDaniel. We really appreciate your feedback! Could you please let us know what exactly is missing in our Node.js documentation so we'll make sure to fix it? Thanks!

Hey @roeeba ,
thanks for the comment

Here's some stuff I had to go through

https://cloudinary.com/documentation/node_image_upload#server_side_upload

cloudinary.v2.uploader.upload_stream : How to set options? Such as as {public_id} ?
Couldn't find anywhere, had to go to the source code and find my self


https://cloudinary.com/documentation/node_image_upload#direct_uploading_from_the_browser
Direct upload from the browser?
isn't that nodejs docs? confusing (browser != nodejs) + many jquery examples, what?

so there's a reference to the upload docs:

https://cloudinary.com/documentation/image_upload_api_reference#upload

> Parameter  = File
> Type = String
> Description:
> 1. a local file path (supported in SDKs only)
> 2. the actual data (byte array buffer). 
> 3. For example, in some SDKs, this could be an IO input stream of the data (e.g., File.open(file, "rb")).
> 4. the Data URI (Base64 encoded), max ~60MB (62,910,000 chars)
> 5. the remote FTP, HTTP or HTTPS URL address of an existing file
> an S3 URL of a whitelisted bucket
> 

2 and 4 doesn't work on the nodejs sdk and the nodejs docs refer to that.
How am I suppose to guess it? why is it documented then? and isn't that very basic thing to allow upload a Buffer? all the nodejs binary data works with buffers, isn't that basic? it only works with uploading a file with a given path to file but
If I already have the file stored on my server, then why do I need cloudinary?
and I guess that your nodejs sdk anyway reads the file as a buffer

Might be very helpful if:
1. support typescript definition
2. write documentation such as jsdoc  
    Example for amazing documentation
    https://draftjs.org/docs/api-reference-content-state.html#content
    Describes all the options in one place with some examples, at cloudinary the docs are just few examples.


So currently I find my self doing
`console.log(cloudinary)`
and getting a huge list  to some how reverse the SDK and understand alone how to use the SDK
 ```
  uploader:
      { unsigned_upload_stream: [Function],
        upload_stream: [Function],
        unsigned_upload: [Function],
        upload: [Function],
        upload_large_part: [Function],
        upload_large: [Function],
        upload_chunked: [Function],
        upload_chunked_stream: [Function],
        explicit: [Function],
        destroy: [Function],
        rename: [Function],
        text: [Function],
        generate_sprite: [Function],
        multi: [Function],
        explode: [Function],
        add_tag: [Function],
        remove_tag: [Function],
        remove_all_tags: [Function],
        add_context: [Function],
        remove_all_context: [Function],
        replace_tag: [Function],
        create_archive: [Function],
        create_zip: [Function],
        direct_upload: [Function],
        upload_tag_params: [Function],
        upload_url: [Function],
        image_upload_tag: [Function],
        unsigned_image_upload_tag: [Function] },
```

which might be helpful if it was documented somewhere
(couldn't find reference to most of it at any place)

For typescript, I've noticed that cloudinary-core does support typings
https://github.com/cloudinary/pkg-cloudinary-core
but as written at the example on the github:

```
var cl = cloudinary.Cloudinary.new();
cl.fromEnvironment();
```

then trying that (EXACTLY as written at the docs) 
```
var cl = cloudinary.Cloudinary.new();
cl.fromEnvironment(); 
```
I get typescript error

> **Property fromEnvironment does not exist on type 'Cloudinary'.**



This was really depressing
I really want to use the Cloudinary product and I find it really good, few years ago I used it
with the IOS sdk and it took me something like 1 hour until there was
images at the cloud. Now it took me more than half day when using the javascript sdk
because it is just not documented

Tried also direct upload from the browser but I didn't want that as solution and we're using React
which makes some stuff harder

I did see cloudinary React
https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary-react
which isn't mentioned at all on the cloudinary website
and isn't documented at all and the docs link doesn't have React at the list

Hey @KromDaniel, wow, thank you very much for the very detailed feedback. Really appreciated! I'm forwarding this to our documentation team to review. We'll do our best to improve the documentation as soon as we can.

@KromDaniel What was your solution to set options inside the upload_stream
I keep getting "Invalid image file" error { message: 'Invalid image file', http_code: 400 } when trying to send raw video/audio data.
I'm guessing that I need to set resource_type: 'raw', but don't see how to do that with the upload_stream.

Also completely agree, documentation is lacking, especially around uploading from buffer/stream, which I would think would be a very common use case for cloudinary.
Wow, it was challenging to track down how to upload a file from a buffer. :/

Regarding Buffers, there's some syntax errors in one of your [examples in your doc](https://cloudinary.com/documentation/node_image_upload) you may want to fix:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5080854/34055616-4f8badea-e1d0-11e7-8404-e410985010fd.png)
@glennreyes Great catch! I have forwarded this to our documentation team.
@zacksayenko thanks it worked for me! you are my hero
The document still has the same error, any one reading this from the official cloudinary team. Kindly update your guides guys.

Hi @adeelibr ,

You are right and we are sorry for that. 
We will fix this ASAP.

Best,
Yakir

Is there anyway of setting the upload filename when uploading from buffer?
```javascript
        cloudinary.v2.uploader.unsigned_upload_stream(preset, (err_cloud, result) => { ... }).end(buffer)
```
We require the original file name, we switched from having to save to disk first to directly upload from buffer but I haven't found anywhere in the docs if it's supported. I did find an old PR that has no answers since 2017 that, I think, tries to add this option.

@shirlymanor we have the following settings in our preset:
```
Folder: pdf 
Use filename: false <<<
Disallow public ID: true <<<
Allowed formats: pdf 
Type: asset 
Access mode: public 
Format: pdf 
Invalidate: true 
Discard original file name: false <<<
```
As you can see, we want a randomly generated public id which will look similar to:

> ://res.cloudinary.com/[cloudname]/image/asset/**fl_attachment**/v[version]/pdf/[random public id].pdf

When uploading with `cloudinary.uploader.unsigned_upload('myfile.pdf',...)` and visiting the url, it will prompt the `Save File` dialog and the displayed name is the original name (e.g: myfile.pdf). However, buffers do not have a filename, so by default it assigns `file` as filename:
https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/c6aa42b11f2b0b97d904f93d2c5794da8c0cdb1b/src/uploader.coffee#L279
The solution is pretty simple, it could check if `options.file` is defined, if not then assign `file` as filename.

Edit: This PR fixes the problem: https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/pull/176

Although the method described above to upload buffers using `upload_stream` works, it feels a bit hacky. I still think the normal `upload` method should support buffers, like it says in the documentation. In that case, there should also be a filename option, similar to what's proposed in #176 for `upload_stream`.
